short-container-title: Journal of the British Society for Phenomenology
title: Perspectives of the Axiological Investigations of the Work of Roman Ingarden

reference.unstructured: In my opinion from the fact that Ingarden did not develop the conception of value while working out the theory of the stratified structure of the literary work of art, it does not follow that the aesthetic value does not constitute the essence of the literary work of art
R. Ingarden:The Literary Work of Art.Northwestern University Press 1974, p. 369.

reference.volume-title: Op. cit.

reference.unstructured: Kraków, 1946, English translation of a later version in R. IngardenInvestigations into the Ontology of Art.Northwestern University Press forthcoming.

The problem of the aesthetic quality-structure of works of art and of aesthetically significant qualities was the center of interest of the Cracow Division of the Section of Aesthetics of the Polish Philosophical Society. At one of the meetings, Ingarden, presenting the problem of the system of aesthetically significant qualities said: “These are the problems, the questions I once wanted to work out, when I undertook all this work, writing, for example, my bookDas literarische Kunstwerk, and thenO budowie obrazu(On the Structure of the Painting),O budowie dziela muzycznego(On the Structure of the Musical Work of Art), etc., where I repeatedly emphasized the point that, for the time being, I was interested solely in that aspect, in that side of the particular phenomena which are (ontologically) basic, that I was not yet interested, therefore, in their values. I did not negate them, I did not at all want to exclude them; I simply wanted to realize the whole work step by step…It became clear that somewhere here, in this foundation, the aesthetically valent or artistically significant qualities would manifest themselves, and that they would even lead to the values.” The passage quoted above is taken from as yet unpublished tape recordings of discussions that took place at meetings of the Cracow Section of Aesthetics (there also exist typed minutes of the meetings). Extensive quotations from these minutes are included in this paper because I believe that these statements are of great significance for Ingarden's axiological conception and allow for a better understanding of his ideas. The passage quoted above is taken from the minutes of the meetings held on December 15, 1962, pp. 6–7.
The minutes of June 6, 1963, pp. 1–2.

R Ingarden: Zagadnienie systemu jakości estetycznie donioslych” (The Problem of the system of aesthetically significant qualities) in,Przezycie-dzielo-wartość(Experience-work of Art-Value) Kraków, 1966 pp 162–194, German version inErlebnis, Kunstwerk und Wert, Tübingen: M. Niemeyer 1969
The minutes of June 6, 1963, p. 11.
The minutes of December 1, 1962, pp. 5–6, and June 6, 1963, p. 15.
The minutes of February 17, 1965, pp. 1–2.
This suggestion deserves special attention since it enables the inclusion of the latest tendencies in art within the range of the investigations.
The minutes of April 27, 1963, pp. 14–15.

The minutes of December 1, 1962, pp. 17–18. Here a qualification seems necessary in order to avoid a confusion between the problem of the manifestation of a definite system ofkindsof aesthetically significant qualities ineverywork of art, and the question of theparticularselection of qualities within agivenwork of art, which selection is decisive for the final qualitative determination of its value. As far as the final value of the work is concerned, Ingarden maintained a definite pluralism: in his opinion there can be many different complexes of qualities which lead to different varieties of aesthetic values. The point may be illustrated by his following remark: “The domain of art is, as a matter of fact, an open domain and it is not yet clear what else may be there included…I do not want to lay down general conditions constitutive of the work of art—this would be extremely inadequate as regards the work of art and the infinite human capacity for inventing unpredictable things…If someone holds that only one way can be followed, then this will soon become a normative, neo-classical theory of aesthetics. There are numerous complexes of aesthetically significant qualities and it is a very nice thing that there are so many different ways which lead to the same objective.” The minutes of February 17, 1965, pp. 25–6.
Cf. R. Ingarden,Przezycie, dzielo, wartosé, p. 191.

“The question is whether a baroque work in a certain baroque style implies a definite series of aesthetically significant qualities and also whether the character of the style determines the complex of aesthetically significant qualities in such a way that, for example, in the Renaissance certain qualities, which are typical of the baroque, could not manifest themselves…This is a new aspect for those who believe that various styles consist in various methods of selecting aesthetically significant qualities, and in the introduction of new values. As a matter of fact, there are reasons for the introduction of a new style only if new values are thus introduced.” The minutes of February 17, 1965, pp. 12–13.
The minutes of April 22, 1963, pp. 1–2.

Ingarden evaluated the results as follows: “My impression is that in all our discussions until now, i.e., in our efforts to identify these qualities, to disclose them, to recognize them and to somehow determine them, we have not reached the intended result We have not proceeded satisfactorily in our attempts to clarify the matter…even when someone was essentially describing the given painting, others came and said whatever just passed through their minds. But these were not worked out ideas…In one thing I do not believe: in the collective work of people who are not prepared for it.” The minutes of February 17, 1965, p. 34.

“The table of qualities here presented may be helpful, but I must stress merely helpful, because what actually speaks to us and what should be listened to is the actual work of art during our commerce with it. As far as our real task is concerned,these schemata of patterns of qualities are merely directions and they certainly are formulated in broad terms, not only in general, but in broad terms(italics mine—A.S.) and so must be differentiated; my suggestion is to do this with reference to actual works of art. Without reference to actual works of art the procedure is too all-embracing, and in a sense scholastic. We shall, however, get ahead if we arrange the qualities, gathering them into certain groups, because their grouping can serve as working hypotheses, useful in further studies.” The minutes of February 17, 1965, p. 4.

Cf, the following statement of Ingarden: “I do not like referring to texts of authors who are not present here…I would rather avoid being tied to a chosen text, but if somebody wants to look up literature on the subject matter we are dealing with and on occasion wants to tell what so-and-so says about it—he will be welcome. I do not want, however, to make it part and parcel of our work.” The minutes of April 15. 1961. p. 2.

The reasons for that are quite obvious. For as Ingarden says: ‘The problem is that I cannot do this because I am a philosopher who is interested in other, general problems. Others may do this who are especially concerned with a given kind of art. Those who deal with literature or music or architecture have better access to those arts. I dared to do such a thing only once—I read Goethe or Schiller or Rilke with my pupils and taught them to read these authors according to my own method. But I have never tried to do it with Polish literature because I did not want to interfere with someone else's business, with the business of men of letters, musicologists, etc. That is why I insist that those who are closer to themétierof a given art should—with my assistance and provided with the problems and the conceptual apparatus—undertake it.” The minutes of February 17, 1965, p. 32.
The minutes of December 15, 1962, p. 29.
